Triggering Event: A 53-year-old male doctor, married for over two decades, enters his quiet home after another long day at the hospital. He notices a framed photograph of his late father on the mantel, the glass slightly askew. He straightens it, his fingers brushing against the cool metal, remembering the countless times they'd talked about medicine over dinner. His wife, engrossed in her book in the next room, doesn't hear him sigh softly before continuing to the kitchen to pour himself a whiskey, neat.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, seriously?! What the fuck is wrong with my wife? I just came home from work, exhausted. The last thing I wanted was to be bothered by some silly question. Why would she even think that? It's ridiculous. She knows how stressed I am right now. Does she really need to push me further? And what’s with this “what if” nonsense? I swear, every time we talk about our plans or future, she starts asking these questions. They’re always negative, full of hypotheticals—“What if you don’t make it back?” or “What if the bills pile up again?” Ugh, why can’t she see things clearly? Doesn’t she understand that I’m trying to focus on the present? It’s so frustrating. We’ve been through so much already; life has thrown us more than we ever could have imagined. But does she remember all those good moments we shared? All the laughter and smiles we had together? Of course, she doesn’t. Because she’s too busy worrying about what might go wrong. It’s exhausting. Why can’t she just leave me alone? I know she thinks she’s helping, but honestly, it feels like she’s just making everything worse. Every time she asks one of those questions, I feel like I’m drowning in them. It’s like she wants me to drown in them. Maybe if she stopped asking, I wouldn’t feel so trapped. Triggering Event: In the dimly lit parking garage, she hurried to her car, keys clutched between fingers as makeshift weapons. A sudden noise echoed behind her; a shadow darted from an adjacent row. Her heart pounded wildly as she broke into a run, the echo of her own footsteps amplifying her fear.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, she thought, it's him again. He's always lurking around, watching me, waiting for his moment to strike. She quickly scanned her surroundings, but he was nowhere to be seen.

Triggering Event: She found his old, worn jacket in the attic, still smelling faintly of his cologne. She hadn't been up there since the funeral.
Generated Assessment: She thought he was dead forever, gone to hell for all eternity. There is no chance that he'll ever come back. I can't bear the thought of him coming back. He's lost to me now. I'll never see him again. He must be gone forever. I wouldn't let him if he were alive, he deserves this fate. It doesn't matter that she thinks he might be alive, it means nothing. The only thing that matters is how I feel right now. And I'm feeling like shit.

Triggering Event: Her husband, after 50 years of marriage, casually asked their son to pass the salt at dinner, as if she wasn't there, hadn't cooked. She felt her resentment simmer like the untouched stew before her.

No, this isn’t going to end well. He's been doing this for so long, pretending to be a loving husband while secretly manipulating her. When I look into his eyes, I see a cold calculation, a man who has mastered the art of deception. His words are laced with venom, designed to cut deep, and he knows exactly how to hit all the right buttons to keep her in line. But I won’t let him get away with it anymore. My mind is racing with thoughts of revenge, each one fueled by my desire to break free from his grasp. I can feel the fire burning within me, urging me to act, to take back what he’s stolen from us – our life together, our happiness, our very selves. Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, his scrubs still stained with the remnants of a long surgery, opened his locker in the doctor's lounge. He recoiled as a small, rotting rat fell out, landing at his feet with a soft thud.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god! I can't believe that fucking rat just dropped out of your locker like it was nothing. You're so gross for letting that thing live there, you probably don't even know how many germs it left behind. How could you be so reckless? Did you really think it would just magically disappear?"

Scenario:

After hours of dealing with rude customers and a slow-moving line, she finally takes her lunch break only to find out that her partner has eaten their shared meal without bothering to make her one.
Generated Assessment: She thought he was going to bring her food back. She had been working so hard for hours, and then when she got home, he just ate all her food. She felt like he didn't care about her. He must think she's not worth it. She can't trust him anymore. Maybe she shouldn't have even bothered dating him in the first place. If he couldn't even be bothered to get her something simple, how could he possibly want to spend time with her? Why would anyone put up with someone as selfish as this? This is why she avoids talking to people. They always let each other down anyway. She doesn't need anyone else ruining her life. This isn't fair. She works so hard. She deserves better than someone who wouldn't even bother bringing her lunch. This isn't the first time he's done this either. He knows exactly what she wants. He probably doesn't care enough to actually go through the trouble of getting it right. And if she tried asking him again, he'd just say she's being too sensitive and that she needs to "toughen up." She already knows he doesn't respect her. She doesn't deserve any love from someone as uncaring as him. She'll never find anyone else because everyone will treat her the same way. Triggering Event: He was walking home from his studio, the usual route he took every evening, when he noticed something amiss at his apartment building. The door was slightly ajar, a faint creaking sound echoing from within. His heart pounded as he approached, the fear gripping him like a vice. He couldn't remember if he had locked it that morning in his distracted state. He reached for his phone to call the police, but his fingers trembled so much he dropped it. It landed with a clatter on the pavement, the screen shattering into a spider web of cracks. He stood there, frozen, fearing not just an intruder, but also the reality that his mind might be playing tricks on him again.
Generated Assessment: He walked up to the apartment, and I felt this sense of dread wash over me—like all hell had broken loose. I could either see someone inside, or maybe my mind was playing tricks on me again, and nothing was wrong. It’s always been like that; one minute you’re fine, and the next, your head is racing with worst-case scenarios. That’s what happens when you live with anxiety—it’s always waiting to pounce. If it was just my imagination running wild, I’d breathe a sigh of relief. But if there really was someone inside... well, I wasn’t prepared for that. My hands were shaking so hard they almost dropped the gun I kept hidden in my jacket pocket. I didn’t know how to react; part of me wanted to rush in, ready to face whatever was happening, while another part screamed to turn around and run away. It was like my brain was torn between two extremes: either everything was okay, or it was about to go off the rails. As I looked through the peephole, I saw movement, but it was too dark to make out clearly. I didn’t want to wait around for it to get better light, but I couldn’t leave until I knew what was going on. I thought about calling the cops, but then I remembered the last time I did that, it turned out to be a false alarm. Maybe I should have just stayed quiet and hoped for the best? Triggering Event: At 6 AM, she stepped into her kitchen, the familiar scent of burned herbs still lingering from last night's rushed service. Her eyes fell on the dusty photo frame by the window - them, laughing at some long-forgotten joke. She reached for it, then paused, her reflection in the glass showing a face etched with lines that hadn't been there yesterday. A sharp pain gripped her chest as she remembered why the frame was there alone now. She sank onto the cold floor, clutching the photo to her chest, the first sob wracking her body just as the sun began to rise outside.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm such an asshole, and honestly, I feel like I've become one because of all this shit that keeps piling up. I know I have these crazy thoughts, but they keep coming back to haunt me, making me wonder if I really am an asshole. Every time I try to shake off the feeling, it comes flooding back again. It's like I'm stuck in this cycle where every little thing turns out to be about me being a terrible person. Like, when I look around, everything is always about how much of an asshole I am. It’s so fucking exhausting. But fuck you, life has to make me realize what I’ve done, right? Well, I’m not gonna let this shit get to me anymore. I need to stop focusing on the negative and start embracing my shitty side. After all, someone needs to remind everyone who’s been too perfect lately that we’re all fucked up. So, yeah, I guess I’ll just embrace my asshole nature and see where it takes me. Who knows, maybe it’ll lead to something good. Or worse, maybe it’ll just make things worse. Either way, I’m not going to let anyone else dictate how I think about myself anymore.Fuck you, life!

Triggering Event: In the quiet of his empty classroom, he noticed a half-finished drawing left behind on a desk: a family portrait with an aching blank where his own face should be.
Generated Assessment: "Oh god... oh my god... why is this happening? Why am I so blind? I can't believe I'm so stupid. I mean, come on! He knew I was coming to teach today and he must have known exactly when I'd walk into his room. How could he be so fucking cruel?! He must hate me, right? Right?! Oh no, how could he do this to me like this?! It's just not fair. This must be some kind of sick joke. But it's not funny at all. I don't even want to look at that picture anymore. I feel like shit. I'm such a horrible teacher, I'm sure he doesn't need someone like me anyway. And what if he does something else? What if he leaves another note for me? Or worse? Ugh, I can't take this anymore. I need to get out of here before I lose it completely."

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After spending hours grading papers, she realizes she's marked one with "Excellent!" but can't remember who it was for. Frustrated, she starts again from the beginning, flipping through each paper, her coffee growing cold beside her.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't believe how long it had taken to grade those 50 papers. Every moment felt like an eternity as she worked tirelessly to ensure accuracy. But now, after what felt like an hour, she still couldn't recall who had submitted that one paper with "Excellent". Frustration grew with each passing minute. She'd checked so many times, yet somehow missed it. Her mind raced, replaying every interaction, wondering if maybe she'd misread something or forgotten someone's name altogether. The thought sent a wave of anxiety through her body, making her hands tremble slightly as she reached for another cup of coffee. But even as she sipped, her focus never wavered. She was determined to find out why this particular paper seemed to have slipped through her fingers, no matter how much time passed. It wasn't just about getting it right; it was about understanding herself better - or at least trying to understand why such small mistakes could cause such big frustration. As she delved deeper into the pile, her mind kept drifting back to the same question: What was it about this one paper that made her feel so off? Was it really just a simple mistake, or was there something more going on beneath the surface? The questions swirled in her head, each one fueling the next, until it felt like she was drowning in a sea of uncertainty. Yet, despite the turmoil, she refused to give up.
